bus.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: a large vehicle that people pay to travel on
bus.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: I took a bus to San Francisco.
Buses run at 15 and 30 minutes past the hour.
There were a lot of people on the bus.
The best way to get there is by bus.
bus.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: a circuit  that connects the main parts of a computer so that signals can be sent from one part of the computer to another
bus.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: I usually go to work by bus.
go on the bus/use the bus
It’s easier to go on the bus than to drive.
Can we get a bus from here to Reading?
It was the first time Craig had ridden a bus downtown by himself.
Several more passengers got on the bus.
We were waiting for the bus for half an hour.
He woke up late and missed the bus.
The last bus went ten minutes ago.
I waited and waited but the bus didn’t come.
The buses run less frequently on a Sunday.
It’s a 20-minute bus ride into town.
She got off at the next bus stop.
Some kids had vandalized the bus shelter.
It’s a small village but there is a good bus service.
We live very near a main bus route.
Can you lend me 50p for my bus fare?
Most of the students have a termly bus pass.
Dad met me at the bus station.
You can be fined for driving in a bus lane.
She asked the bus driver where to get off for the Botanical Gardens.
The bus timetable changes on January 31st.
We were chatting while we stood in the bus queue.
Hurry up or you’ll miss the school bus!
There’s a shuttle bus between the hotel and the beach.
London used to be famous for its double-decker buses.
We took a tour on an open-topped bus.
Regular buses run to the airport.
bus.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with bus
You usually say get on a bus  ‘Get in’ is much less common
I got on the bus at the station
You usually say get off a bus  ‘Get out of’ is much less common
She got off the bus at her usual stop
You usually say that someone is on a bus  ‘In a bus’ is much less common
All the people on the bus stared at me
The children travel to school by bus
You often talk about the bus
It’s quicker if you take the bus
I was waiting for the bus for the airport
bus.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: bus
a large vehicle that people pay to travel on
There were a lot of people on the bus.
coach
a bus with comfortable seats used for long journeys
Taking the coach is cheaper than the train.
minibus
a small bus with seats for six to twelve people
The school uses a minibus to take teams to matches.
double-decker
a bus with two levels
the red double-deckers in London
articulated bus
a very long bus that has a joint in the middle that allows it to go around corners
Articulated buses have been used in Europe for many years.
tram
a vehicle for passengers, which travels along metal tracks in the street, and usually gets power from electric lines over the vehicle
We waited at the stop for the tram.
San Diego has a well-used trolley system.
tram
a vehicle with many different parts for people to sit in, and which usually has open sides. A tram runs on wheels and is used to take tourists from place to place within a particular area
The tram takes visitors around the backlot of Universal Studios, where many famous movies were once made.
bus.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to take a person or a group of people somewhere in a bus
bus.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: Casey was bussed to the school.
bus.translation[1].definitions[0].note_b: Bus is often passive in this meaning
bus.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: to take away dirty dishes from the tables in a restaurant
bus.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: Shelley had a job bussing tables.
